He saw a father and son plowing the fields, and a poisonous snake bit and killed the son.
The father continued plowing without looking at his son or crying.
The brahman asked:
Whose son is this?
The plowman replied:
He is my son.
The brahman said:
If this is your son, why don't you cry but plow as usual?
That person replied:
When people are born they will die, when things are formed they will decay, the good will be rewarded, the evil will be opposed, what is the use of grieving and crying?
Even if you don't eat or drink, what benefit is there to a dead person?
You should enter the city now. My house is at such-and-such place. Please go and tell them:
'Your son has already died.
You don't need to bring food for two people.'
The brahman thought to himself:
This person has no gratitude. His child died on the ground, yet he is not sorrowful but instead asks for food.
This person is unfilial and has no equal.
The brahman then went into the city and went to the farmer's house. Seeing the dead child's mother, he immediately said to her:
Your child has already died.
The father said:
'Just bring food for one person.
Why don't you think of your child?'
The child's mother spoke a parable in reverse for the brahman, saying:
A child is like a guest, coming to rely on a person to stay.
When coming, one does not turn them away; when leaving, one does not keep them.
This child originally belonged to me. I did not call them to come. They came and passed through my life, and when they die, they will also leave on their own.
It is not my power that causes them to advance or retreat, but follows their original actions in pursuing the life they are to be reborn into.
He also said to his sister:
Your younger brother has already died, why don't you cry?
The sister then spoke a parable to the brÄhman, saying:

We siblings are like a craftsman who enters the mountains to cut down trees, binds them into a large raft, places it in the water, but suddenly encounters a great wind that blows the raft apart and scatters it, following the water and flowing away, with the front and back parts separated and not looking at each other.
My younger brother is also like this. In this way, due to causes and conditions from past lives, we temporarily came together and were born in the same family.
Following the length of life, birth and death are impermanent, and what comes together will be separated.
My younger brother's life has ended, and we each follow our own path.
Impermanence arrives in front of us, and we cannot save each other according to our original actions.
He also said to the wife of the deceased:
Your husband has already died, why don't you cry?
The wife then spoke a parable for the brÄhman, saying:
My wife and I, our causes and conditions brought us together for a short while.
It is like flying birds roosting in a tall tree in the evening, staying together for the night, and at dawn each flies away to seek food and drink.
When there are causes and conditions, they come together; when there are no causes and conditions, they part.
My wife and I are also like this, our coming and going, advancing and stopping are not due to our own power.
When impermanence arrives, we follow our original life, unable to save each other.
He also said to his slave:
Your master's son has died, why don't you cry?
The slave again spoke a parable:
My master, due to causes and conditions, we came together.
I am like a calf following a large ox.
When a person kills the large ox, the calf is by the side, unable to save the large ox.
The impermanent life cannot be saved, so why be sorrowful, crying will also do no good.
When the brahman heard this, his mind was confused, his eyes were closed, and he did not know east from west:

I heard that the people of this country are filial, follow the Way, make offerings to the Three Jewels, and therefore came from afar wishing to study, but have not received a good response, and have seen five unfilial people.
Toiling my body and mind, I came far to this place, but have gained nothing.
He also asked the travelers:
Where is the Buddha?
I wish to go and ask him.
The travelers replied:
He is nearby, in the Jetavana Monastery.
The brahman then went to where the Buddha was, bowed at the Buddha's feet in reverence, sat to one side with a sorrowful face, and said nothing.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and said to the brahman:
Why do you lower your head?
Why are you sorrowful and unhappy?
The brahman said to the Buddha:
My wishes have not been fulfilled, contrary to my original intention, and therefore I am sorrowful.
The Buddha asked:
What have you lost that you are sorrowful and unhappy?

His mother, wife, and sister, and the slave, were all without sorrow.
This is a great offense and lack of filial piety.
The Buddha said:
It is not so, not as you say.
These five people are the most filial, knowing that life is impermanent, not to be reached by sorrow.
Even the sages of the past did not escape this calamity, let alone ordinary people. What benefit is there in the dead crying loudly and the living crying little?
Worldly laypeople have been wandering in birth and death for countless eons, their spirits transmigrate without ceasing, dying and being reborn again, like a turning wheel with no rest.
Turning away from death and toward life, it is not reached by worry and sorrow.
When the brahmin heard this, his mind opened up and his thoughts were resolved, and he no longer had any worries or distress:
I have heard the Buddha's teachings, like a sick person being cured, like the blind gaining sight, like darkness encountering light.
Then the brahmin attained the path of a stream-enterer.
All deaths are not enough to cry over. For the sake of the deceased, invite the Buddha and the Sangha, burn incense and make offerings, and recite the scriptures.
Being able to make offerings with utmost sincerity day after day is the most important thing.
Then the brahmin bowed his head in reverence, received the teachings, and left.
